key_points: Colin Powell, former U.S. Secretary of State and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has died at 84 from Covid complications.
Despite being fully vaccinated, Powell had underlying conditions, including Parkinson's disease and multiple myeloma, a type of blood cancer.
Powell served as the nation's first Black national security advisor, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and secretary of State.
Tributes have been received from various leaders including former Presidents George W. Bush, Barack Obama, and contemporary Condoleezza Rice.
President Joe Biden ordered flags to be lowered in Powell's honor and described him as embodying the highest ideals of both warrior and diplomat.
Powell endorsed Democrats Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton in their presidential campaigns, despite identifying as a Republican.
Powell admitted that his support for the Iraq War, which began in 2003, haunted him and considered it a blot on his record.
Powell was the son of Jamaican immigrants and made history as the first Black person to serve as national security advisor.
His role in arguing for the U.S.'s invasion of Iraq was seen as a significant aspect of his legacy, despite his later regrets.
The Bush administration's decision to invade Iraq, supported by Powell's UN speech claiming Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, was later criticized as an intelligence failure.
spokespersons: Condoleezza Rice (Powell's successor at the State Department)
